Diwali marks the return of Bhagwan Ram from exile after killing Ravan for his unrighteousness way of life involving touching(grabbing onto the hand) of a married woman therefore symbolizing victory of truth and righteousness over lies and unrighteousness way of life concomitantly it marks several other tales such as Mata Kaali's pooja and and Bhagwan Krishna defeating a rakchas named Narkasura; my point is it is more important for the people who celebrate especially the youth to take learnings from these festivals first then the sweets and bursting crackers because they light the way a good human being should walk on.
I hope you truly enjoyed the festival, certainly it can be rather heavy if its your first time especially when you're not used to the noise, but the moment with your loved ones engulfed in joy and happiness envelopes the noise and makes the moment remarkable, personally the pooja and rangolis and decorating the house are my favorite part as they help people bond not just families but everyone, would love to know how you felt about your experience.

PS; the poojas can get boring given the mantras are in Sanskrit a way around is understanding its meaning which in itself is a story and makes every pooja more interesting and easier to dedicate oneself to it that is if you wish. 

stay blessed, happy and may you all have a happy and prosperous life

â€¢ Try to have short, frequent meals.
â€¢ Include protein and fibre in every meal â€” paneer, sprouts, dal, rajma, chole, lobia, kadhi, and soya (if your thyroid levels are stable), etc.
â€¢ Add 1 tsp of roasted flax seeds to your diet.
â€¢ A small serving of roasted chana before bed may help with fasting sugar levels.
â€¢ Try to walk for at least 15 minutes after meals.
â€¢ Prenatal yoga can also help â€” practice according to your placenta position and medical advice.
â€¢ Prioritise good sleep, as pregnancy hormones, stress, and sleep quality are closely connected.

1. I walked for 20-30 minutes right after each mealâ€”after breakfast, lunch, my 4 oâ€™clock snack, and dinner. So, I used to walk around 80-100 minutes each day.
2. I ate lots of protein and veggies, and only a small amount of carbohydrates.

You are truly the ultimate stress-buster for everyone who watches your blogs, so please also take a moment to relax and enjoy!

Take care and happy pregnancy!

You can reduce wheat flour and wheat chapatis in your diet and switch to mixed flours like bajra, jowar, or multigrain atta. These help in controlling blood sugar because wheat flour has more carbohydrates and digests faster, which can raise sugar levels more quickly.

I am suggesting this because my grandfather is going through liver cancer treatment, and we also need to manage his sugar levels, so we have replaced wheat flour with healthier mixed-flour options.

Pregnancy mein sugar control rakhna bahut zaroori hota hai,  Khane-peene par dhyan dena sabse effective tarika hai. Din bhar mein thoda-thoda karke 5â€“6 baar khana khaayein aur meethi cheezein jaise chini, mithai, cold drink, cake, biscuit wagaira ko avoid karein. Chawal aur safed roti kam lein, aur fiber wale foods jaise daliya, brown rice, multigrain roti, salad aur hari sabziyon ko diet ka hissa banaayein. Phal theek hote hain, lekin aam, angoor, banana jaise zyada meethay phal kam khaayein. Protein ke liye daal, anda, doodh, chana, rajma jaise foods bahut faydemand hote hain. Roz 8â€“10 glass paani piyein aur meetha juice bilkul na lein. Rozana 30 minute halki walk karna, aur khane ke baad 15â€“20 minute chalna sugar ko naturally control mein rakhta hai.

Hi. If your having gestation diabetes
Tea drink without sugar. 
Stop eating rice - you can switch to quinoa or any millet that has low glycemic index
Also roti breaks down into sugar once eaten. Stop eating regular wheat atta roti. Switch to gluten free atta or Ragi atta roti. 
Also fruits depending on what you eat can increase sugar levels. So google and do research on which fruits you should eat and avoid in case of elevated sugar levels. 
Hope you feel better. And all the best

To lower the sugar levels, our specialist in Canada and all doctors in Canada recommended these steps - no gap or fasting more than 4-5.5 hours in between meals ( have some small snacks in between), walk 15-20 mins minimum after meals, after dinner have some milk (3 hour gap after dinner) or something lighter with protein source before going to bed and between last food at night (eg. milk around 9 pm) and eat something in morning around 6.30 -7 am or so. Hi Bharti. I am from US. When i got gestational diabetes during pregnancy I was sent to registered dietitian who educated me how many carbs is in 1 roti, 1 cup of dal, or any subzi. They basically gave me food chart that said 2 dhokla is 30 gms of carbs as an example. Also during pregnancy you should not skip carbs. I was told to eat 160 gms of carbs a day for proper brain development of the baby. I was eating breakfast, snack, lunch, snack, dinner, bedtime snack. My post meal sugar was controlled with exercise. So after every meal i walked for 30 mins. When it rained, i had stationary bike so
I used to bike. Fasting was still something i couldnt control so i was put on metformin small dose at bedtime. If sugar is high the baby is going to be huge. So you will also have frequent ultrasounds.
I am wondering why your doctor is not educating you and just saying eat healthy. Even if you eat millets, 3 roti is lot of carbs. Your blood sugar will spike. Add atleast 30 grams of protein per meal. Add healthy fats and fiber. I used to eat 1 roti because i had dal, subzi, yogurt and all has carbs. Hope this helps.

Mam ji pregnancy,Â take a balanced diet as per doctor's advice, which includes less carbohydrates and more fiber.Â Get regular, moderate exercise, monitor your blood sugar levels, take medications (such as insulin) as directed by your doctor, and reduce stress.Â 
Diet and nutrition
Fiber-rich foods: Choose fiber-rich foods like whole grains, pulses, and whole oats. 
Consumption of fruits and vegetables: Eat fruits and vegetables at least 5 times a day. 
Avoid sweet and processed foods: Avoid cakes, biscuits, and sweetened beverages and choose healthier options like fruits and nuts. 
Foods with a low glycemic index: Low-glycemic index foods like poha help in keeping the blood sugar levels stable. 
Natural remedies: Fenugreek water and cinnamon water can also be beneficial. 
Drink enough water: Drink enough water to keep the body hydrated. 
Lifestyle and exercise
regular exercise: Do light exercise as per doctor's advice. 
Reduce stress: Avoid stress, smoking and staying up late at night. 
Avoid alcohol: Avoid alcohol during pregnancy. 
medical assistance
Blood sugar monitoring: Check your blood sugar levels regularly at home. 
See your doctor regularly: Stay in regular contact with your doctor for prenatal care and follow his/her advice. 
Medicines and insulin: If necessary, take insulin or other medicines as per doctor's advice. 
Reviews of drugs: Talk to your doctor about your diabetes medications, as some may not be safe during pregnancy. 
Eye and kidney tests: It is very important to get your kidneys and eyes checked, so consult a doctor.

Hi, Iâ€™m a nutritionist Suprina, let me explain something important.

Your blood sugar can still go high during pregnancy even if you donâ€™t eat sweets or feel stressed. It happens because the placenta releases hormones that make your body insulin-resistant. So your body doesnâ€™t use glucose properly and sugar levels rise.

Also remember â€” itâ€™s not just sugar. Foods like rice, roti, potatoes, milk, bread and fruits also convert into glucose. This is common in pregnancy and is called gestational diabetes.

Now how to control it:

âœ… Eat small frequent meals (3 meals + 2â€“3 healthy snacks)
âœ… Choose better carbs like oats, dal, brown rice, whole wheat roti, veggies
âŒ Limit white rice, potatoes, bread, pasta, sweets and juices
âœ… Add protein every time you eat â€” eggs, dal, paneer, chicken, curd, nuts
ğŸš¶â€â™€ï¸ Walk 10â€“20 mins after meals

ğŸ’Š And if diet & walking arenâ€™t enough, medicine or insulin may be needed â€” and itâ€™s safe for the baby.

Managing your sugar will help prevent complications and keep both you and your baby healthy. ğŸ’›

Hi Bharti, due to hormonal fluctuations, variations in glucose levels are usually normal.
